hints_html: Try setting the numerator and the denominator to 0. What does a value of 0 in the numerator correspond to? How about when the denominator is 0?
hints_latex:
Try setting the numerator and the denominator to 0. What does a value of
0 in the numerator correspond to? How about when the denominator is 0?
hints_raw: Try setting the numerator and the denominator to 0. What does a value of 0 in the numerator correspond to? How about when the denominator is 0?
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
To determine where f"(x)=0, we look at the numerator of f"(x) and note that f"(x)=0 when the numerator is zero, i.e.

\[\begin{aligned} 2x(x^2+9)=0.\end{aligned}\]

Since x2+9=0 has no real solutions, the only value of x that satisfies the above equation is when x=0.

To determine where f"(x) does not exist, we set the denominator to 0, i.e.

\[\begin{aligned} x^2-3=0.\end{aligned}\]

So, f"(x) does not exist when \(x=\pm\sqrt 3\).

”Remark: Note that the denominator and numerator are never simultaneously 0. If they were, say at x=a, we would have to take the limit of f"(x) as \(x \rightarrow a\) to determine if f"(x) did not exist or was zero (or another finite number).”
sols_latex:
To determine where \emph{f"(x)=0}, we look at the numerator of
\emph{f"(x)} and note that \emph{f"(x)=0} when the numerator is zero,
i.e.

\begin{align*}
2x(x^2+9)=0.
\end{align*} Since \emph{x\textsuperscript{2}+9=0} has no real
solutions, the only value of \emph{x} that satisfies the above equation
is when \emph{x=0}.

To determine where \emph{f"(x)} does not exist, we set the denominator
to 0, i.e.

\begin{align*}
x^2-3=0.
\end{align*} So, \emph{f"(x)} does not exist when $x=\pm\sqrt 3$.

''Remark: Note that the denominator and numerator are never
simultaneously 0. If they were, say at \emph{x=a}, we would have to take
the limit of \emph{f"(x)} as $x \rightarrow a$ to determine if
\emph{f"(x)} did not exist or was zero (or another finite number).''
sols_raw:
To determine where  ''f"(x)=0'', we look at the numerator of ''f"(x)'' and note that ''f"(x)=0'' when the numerator is zero, i.e. 
:<math> 2x(x^2+9)=0.</math>
Since ''x<sup>2</sup>+9=0'' has no real solutions, the only value of ''x'' that satisfies the above equation is when ''x=0''.


To determine where ''f"(x)'' does not exist, we set the denominator to 0, i.e.
:<math>x^2-3=0.</math>
So, ''f"(x)'' does not exist when <math>x=\pm\sqrt 3</math>.


''Remark: Note that the denominator and numerator are never simultaneously 0. If they were, say at ''x=a'', we would have to take the limit of ''f"(x)'' as <math>x \rightarrow a</math> to determine if ''f"(x)'' did not exist or was zero (or another finite number).''
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{x^3+x^2-2x-3}{x^2-3}\end{aligned}\]

Its first and second derivatives are given by

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) = \frac{(x^2-1)(x^2-6)}{(x^2-3)^2}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} f''(x) = \frac{2x(x^2+9)}{(x^2-3)^3}\end{aligned}\]

Find all x such that f\(^{\prime\prime}\)(x) = 0 or f\(^{\prime\prime}\)(x) does not exist.
statement_raw:
Consider the function
:<math>
f(x) = \frac{x^3+x^2-2x-3}{x^2-3}
</math>

Its first and second derivatives are given by
:<math>
f'(x) = \frac{(x^2-1)(x^2-6)}{(x^2-3)^2}
</math>
and
:<math>
f''(x) = \frac{2x(x^2+9)}{(x^2-3)^3}
</math>

Find all ''x'' such that f′′(x) = 0 or f′′(x) does not exist.
